blogs.title: Building Reliable Agentic AI Systems in Production
blogs.excerpt: How I design agent workflows that are observable, evaluable, and production-ready.
content: Reliable agentic systems are less about prompt tricks and more about architecture: structured state, deterministic orchestration, and measurable outcomes.
I prefer LangGraph-style explicit state machines because they make failure handling and retries predictable under real traffic.
Observability is non-negotiable. End-to-end traces, evaluation checkpoints, and quality metrics are what let teams ship quickly without losing control.

blogs.title: RAG Pipelines for Real Product Environments
blogs.excerpt: Design patterns for retrieval systems that stay robust beyond demos.
content: Most RAG failures come from weak ingestion and poor schema discipline, not model quality.
I focus on structured ingestion, validation, chunking strategy, and retrieval scoring before tuning model prompts.
When retrieval quality is treated like a backend reliability problem, user-facing quality improves dramatically.

blogs.title: AI Observability with a Self-Hosted Langfuse Stack
blogs.excerpt: What changed after introducing tracing, evaluation, and metrics into agent workflows.
content: Self-hosting observability gave us full control over traces, evaluations, and data boundaries.
The biggest benefit was faster iteration: regressions became visible early, and prompt or retrieval changes were easier to validate.
In AI products, observability is a product velocity multiplier, not just a monitoring feature.
